description: From Middle English reprise (noun) and reprisen (verb), from Old French reprise, from reprendre.

entries.meaning: A recurrence or resumption of an action.
(music) A repetition of a phrase, a return to an earlier theme, or a second rendition or version of a song in a programme or musical.
(fencing) A renewal of a failed attack, after going back into the en garde position.
A taking by way of retaliation.
examples: Your care about your banks infers a fear Of threatening floods ,and inundations near; If so, a just reprise would only be Of what the land usurped upon the sea

entries.meaning: (law, in the plural) Deductions and duties paid yearly out of a manor and lands, as rent charge, pensions, annuities, etc.; also spelled reprizes
A ship recaptured from an enemy or from a pirate.
(construction) In masonry, the return of a moulding in an internal angle.

verbs.description: reprise (third-person singular simple present reprises, present participle reprising, simple past and past participle reprised)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To take (something) up or on again.
To repeat or resume an action
examples: The aging actress played the role she played in her youth, as if to reprise it.
